Situation1: They send an occasional text to check in with their parents over the weekend.
Expectation2: Conduct daily prayers and religious services for the community
Situation2: Should attend the most significant religious holiday of the year, which draws the largest attendance.
Story: I stared at my phone, the screen lighting up with a message from my mother: “Will you call us this weekend? We miss you.” I knew she and Dad waited for my voice, our weekly ritual of laughter and stories. But this weekend was different. As the priest of our small town, I was expected to lead the most significant religious holiday of the year. The congregation would fill every pew, their eyes on me for guidance, comfort, and tradition. My mind raced with preparations—sermons, prayers, the logistics of the service. Yet, my heart tugged toward home, to the warmth of my parents’ voices, their simple need to hear from their son. The weight of both worlds pressed on me: the community’s spiritual needs and my family’s longing for connection. I felt torn, guilt rising no matter which way I leaned. My thumb hovered over the call button, the church bells echoing in the distance, as I wrestled with the impossible choice between duty and love.
